Okay, now for what you actually clicked for.

If you like to travel (especially across borders),
a passport is one of the most important things
you can own.

Passports are sophisticated marvels of modern
technology designed to make it easier for

the average traveler to cross a border, for
a host country to know who is coming in and

going out, and for certain annoying commenters
on my videos to call them “slave IDs”.

But how did they cross borders in the ancient
world?

Was there some kind of equivalent to passports
in antiquity?

Well, in the ancient world, things were (kind
of unsurprisingly) quite different from today.

Ancient empires couldn’t necessarily defend
long borders, and borders were often quite

a bit more porous and not always strict lines
in the ground.

Thus, borders as we know them today were kind
of impossible in the ancient world, and were

more like frontiers, with each side being
kind of a sovereignty gradient, and was more

focused on keeping out invading armies than
illegal immigrants and smugglers.

This was a time long before before Westphalian
sovereignty, and the borders of the various

kingdoms and empires were of course incredibly
fluid, with borders changing pretty much every
few months in some places at some times.

I mean, just watch an EmperorTigerstar video
and try to see where any ancient empire could
set up a hard border.

Of course, travel itself was also not as common
as it is today.

People did still travel though, and often
needed to travel between the different empires
of the day.

The first mention of any form of cross-border
travel document we have is found in the Hebrew

Bible, specifically Nehemiah 2:7-9, when Persian
official Nehemiah asked King Artaxerxes I

for a letter to give to “the governors beyond
the river” requesting they give him safe
passage on his way to Judea.

In China however, everyone who wanted to travel
throughout the different imperial counties

required a special document called “zhuan”,
which detailed height, age and bodily features
of the holder in question.

Later on, in the time of the Islamic Caliphates,
their basic passport was something called

a “bara’a”, which granted the user permission
to travel to different parts of the Islamic

realm, but only if they had paid their taxes,
be they zakat or jizya.

So, in a sense it was more like a passport
granted as a receipt for paying your taxes,

a little like showing your ticket to a fare
inspector on the metro so you can get on the
train.

Passports further evolved over in Europe,
especially in 15th and 16th century England,

starting with documents for English subjects
to prove who they were in foreign lands, and
the invention of the word “passport”.

“Pass” coming from the French “passer”
meaning to pass through, and “port” coming

from the French “port” referring to seaports,
a means of passing through a port of entry.

First mentioned in the Safe Conducts Act of
1414, these safe conduct documents were usually

notes signed by the monarch asking the bearer
be granted safe passage, and were often even
granted to foreign subjects, not just Englishmen.

The development of the passport however was
thrown into overdrive with the invention of
easier modes of transport, especially railroads.

Trains helped shrink both Europe and North
America, but we’re going to focus on Europe

first because Schengen didn’t exist back
then (well, I’m sure the village did, but
still).

As a result of so many people suddenly being
able to travel so far so quickly, passport
requirements were actually lowered.

Around the world, crossing borders as a civilian
was actually very easy, and passports weren’t
often required.

After all, the only other alternative while
everything was figured out was apocalyptic
gridlock.

In fact, when new immigrants came on the boats
to the US-- whose borders were relatively

open-- their passage through Ellis Island
was mainly to process new arrivals as they

came into the US (as long as they weren’t
part of an “inadmissible group”, of course),

and also make sure they were clear on the
whole having-diseases front.

However, during World War the-one-without-the-Nazis,
the borders of Europe were obviously closed…
and also not exactly very crossable either.

After the war ended though, in 1920 the League
of Nations had a talk, and they organized

a system that gave birth to the passport booklet
as we know it today.

Before this time, passports were still basically
just sheets of paper with the bearer’s identity
that another country could stamp.

Passports were then standardized after the
International Civil Aviation Organization

(ICAO) got their hands on it in 1980, making
passports all machine-readable for easier
entry across borders.

To avoid counterfeit, countries are also using
various new security features, from biometric

data to holograms to the little electronics
that are the reason you really shouldn’t
bend your passport.

Nowadays, every country in the world has a
passport in all different kinds of… well,

actually four different base colors, one size,
and one general shape, but also have all kinds
of different features representing their countries.

For example, the New Zealand passport has
Māori translations on it, the US and Canadian

passports depict patriotic scenes from their
countries, Russia grants its citizens different

passports for both internal and external use,
and this East German passport is actually
a notebook I got in Friedrichstraße.

The point is, while we are at a point where
just about every country, territory, or group

of countries requires one to use a passport
to get in (often also needing a visa on top

of that), it is now arguably easier than ever
to get a passport, hundred of millions-- if

not billions-- of people already have one,
which accompany them on the thousands of flights

that cross an international border every single
day.
